teaching.topicContent: Introduce the various parts of speech (nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, pronouns, prepositions, conjunctions, interjections) and discuss parsing sentences to identify these parts.

teaching.topicTitle: One Word: Different Parts of Speech
teaching.topicContent: Explore how a single word can function as different parts of speech based on its context. Teach how to identify these variations.
Introduce proofreading techniques to check for errors in writing. Teach students to identify and correct spelling, punctuation, and grammatical mistakes.

teaching.topicTitle: Noun Phrases as Subjects and Objects
teaching.topicContent: Explore how noun phrases can function as subjects and objects in sentences. Teach how to identify and use noun phrases effectively.
Teach compound subjects (two or more subjects) and compound objects (two or more objects) in sentences. Discuss their usage and agreement with verbs.
Continue exploring homophones with additional pairs that are often confused. Discuss their meanings and practice differentiating their usage.
Introduce homographs (words with the same spelling but different meanings) and homonyms (words that sound the same but have different meanings).
Deepen understanding of homographs and homonyms by discussing how context helps determine their meanings in sentences.
Review antonyms and synonyms. Teach how antonyms are opposite in meaning, while synonyms have similar meanings. Encourage vocabulary exploration.
Introduce definite articles (the) and indefinite articles (a, an). Explain when and how to use these articles with nouns.
Teach the difference between countable (can be counted) and uncountable (cannot be counted individually) nouns. Discuss their usage and plural forms.
Review the various parts of speech and their functions in sentences. Provide examples and engage students in identifying each part of speech.
Introduce direct and indirect objects in sentences. Explain their roles and how they relate to verbs and subjects.
Introduce relative clauses (adjective clauses) and how they provide additional information about a noun. Teach how to identify and use them.
Discuss how to integrate relative clauses into sentences. Provide examples and guide students in creating complex sentences with relative clauses.
Introduce coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so, for, yet, nor). Explain how they connect words, phrases, or clauses in sentences.
Introduce the active and passive voice. Teach how the subject performs the action in the active voice and receives the action in the passive voice.
Further explore the passive voice, its formation, and its usage in sentences. Discuss how the passive voice can change sentence focus.
Introduce gerunds (verb forms ending in -ing) and how they function as nouns in sentences. Discuss their usage and provide examples.
Explore idiomatic expressions (phrases with figurative meanings) and their usage in everyday language. Provide examples and discuss their meanings.
Teach imperative sentences (commands and requests) and how they are formed. Provide examples and practice creating imperative sentences.
Discuss the importance of using paragraphs to organize writing. Teach how to achieve cohesion within and between paragraphs.
Explore the differences between formal and informal writing styles. Discuss appropriate contexts for each style and provide examples.
Continue exploring homophones with additional pairs that are often confused. Discuss their meanings and practice differentiating their usage.
Review antonyms and synonyms. Teach how antonyms are opposite in meaning, while synonyms have similar meanings. Encourage vocabulary exploration.
Introduce expository writing and its purpose to inform or explain. Teach the structure of expository essays and provide guidance on creating clear and organized writing.

test.description: Put your Word study knowledge to the test.

questions.content: Identify the prefix in the word 'unfriendly'.
What is the superlative form of the adverb 'quickly'?
What is the antonym for 'confident'?
In which sentence is the word 'where' used correctly?
Identify the object pronoun in the sentence: 'She gave him a present.'
What is the correct usage of the homophone 'you're'?
answers: You're book is on the table.

questions.content: What does the suffix '-al' turn a noun into?
Choose the correct adjective: 'His ____________ voice sounded soothing.'
What is the purpose of using ellipsis (...) in writing?
answers: To mark the end of a sentence.
To show omitted words or create suspense.

questions.content: What is the role of hyphens (-) in compound adjectives?
Identify the comparative adjective in the sentence: 'She is taller than her brother.'
What is the role of an infinitive in a sentence?
answers: To serve as the base form of a verb.

questions.content: What is the prefix in the word 'submarine'?
Which sentence is a compound-complex sentence?
answers: She studied hard, and she aced the test.

What is the plural form of the word 'man'?
Identify the part of speech for the word 'quickly' in the sentence: 'She runs quickly.'
What is the purpose of proofreading in writing?
Identify the noun phrase in the sentence: 'The big blue sky stretched above us.'
Choose the correct usage of the homophone 'to' in a sentence.
answers: I saw the cat to times.

questions.content: What is the difference between homographs and homonyms?
answers: Homographs are singular, and homonyms are plural.
Homographs have the same spelling but different meanings, while homonyms sound the same but have different meanings.
Homographs have opposite meanings, and homonyms have similar meanings.
Homographs have the same meaning, and homonyms have different meanings.

questions.content: Which of the following is an indefinite article?
Identify the conjunction in the sentence: 'She wanted to go to the park, but it started raining.'
What is the active voice of the sentence: 'The book was read by the teacher.'?
answers: The teacher read the book was.
The teacher was read by the book.
The book was reading by the teacher.

questions.content: Choose the correct usage of the gerund in a sentence.
answers: She loves to play the piano.

questions.content: What is the purpose of using idiomatic expressions in writing?
answers: To convey figurative meanings and add color to language.

questions.content: Identify the imperative sentence: 'Please close the door.'
What is the coordinating conjunction in the sentence: 'She is talented and hardworking.'
Choose the correct article for the noun 'apple':
In the sentence 'The letter was written by Sarah.', what is the direct object?
What is the role of relative clauses ('who','which etc) in sentences?
answers: To provide additional information about a noun.

questions.content: What is the plural form of the compound noun 'mother-in-law'?
Identify the adverb in the sentence: 'They walked quietly through the forest.'
What is the purpose of using hyphens (-) in numbers?
answers: To connect words in compound numbers e.g Twenty-four.

questions.content: Identify the conjunction in the sentence: 'She likes  ice cream and cake.'

Choose the correct passive voice of the sentence: 'They are building a new school.'
answers: A new school is being built by them.
A new school being built are by them.
A new school is building by them.
They building a new school are.

questions.content: What is the function of the coordinating conjunction 'but' in a sentence?
In the sentence 'She hopes to win the competition.', what is the infinitive phrase?
What is the function of idiomatic expressions in writing?
answers: To make the writing more complex.
To convey figurative meanings in a creative way e.g 'Break a leg!'.
